Graphical abstract The doping of Ce additive into Cu-ZnO catalyst could stabilize the ratio of Cu0/Cu+ on catalyst surface and retard oxidation of metallic Cu species to Cu2+, thereby improving the catalyst stability. Cu-ZnO based catalysts are of industrial importance for methanol synthesis. In this work, Cu-ZnO-CeO2 (CZCe) catalyst has been prepared via conventional co-precipitation technique and applied for syngas hydrogenation to methanol with the purpose to study the effect of reversible redox metal oxide (ceria) on the distribution of valence state of active Cu species. Herein, CZCe catalyst exhibited the outstanding catalytic performance with initial methanol yield as high as 0.665 g·g–1 cat.·h–1 and the STYMeOH could well be maintained with a high value (0.600 g·g–1 cat.·h–1) at 230 °C after 70 h of evaluation, which exceeded the reference Cu-ZnO-Al2O3 (CZAl) catalyst prepared by the same method. The excellent performance could be attributed to ceria doping tended to dynamically tune the distributions and/or concentrations of Cu+ and Cu° species on the catalyst surfaces and retard the conversion of Cu δ + (δ < 2) to Cu2+ in the process of reaction. Keywords Methanol Syngas hydrogenation CZCe Cu0/Cu+ Stability 1 Introduction With the emergence of severe resource and environmental crisis, methanol synthesis has attracted extensive interest because of its significant demand, easy storage and transportation, as well as the abundance of feedstock. Methanol has been widely used for chemical and energy industries. As a crucial organic feedstock, the applications for the synthesis of value-added products (such as formaldehyde [1], dimethyl carbonate [2] and light olefins [3–5] etc.) are of great interest and it has been also considered as a promising additive or alternative for replacing gasoline-based liquid fuel due to its higher octane value and less air pollution than conventional fossil oil. Methanol synthesis from syngas hydrogenation is one of the essential methods to make the efficient utilization of coal, natural gas, biomass and even CO2 in the reality. This reaction involved the activation of CO bonds and the formation of CH and OH bonds. Given its promising catalytic activity and easily available features different from others such as Au [6], Pd [7] and Ag-based catalysts, there are definite advantages to select Cu-based catalysts for CO bond hydrogenation reactions from either an environmental or economic perspective [8]. However, Cu-ZnO based nanocatalysts with considerable catalytic activity and selectivity have an intrinsic problem, i.e. poor stability under work conditions. Consequently, to improve stability of Cu-ZnO based catalysts is of interest to us. Generally, two main causes can be responsible for its poor stability. One is the loss of active copper surface through particle growth due to sintering and Ostwald ripening in work conditions, which also can interrupt the distribution of Cu0 and Cu+, thereby accelerating the catalyst deactivation. However, much work which based on modification of the chemistry and/or increased physical barriers has been done to prevent particle aggregation [9–12]. Our group has previously accessed stable CuZnO/SiO2 methanol synthesis catalyst via rotary evaporation assisted deposition precipitation method due to the relieving Ostwald ripening effect [13]. In contrast, as another prominent reason, the development of the valence transformation of cupreous species as a result of electronic effects between metal (oxides) and/or support and/or reactants is relatively dull. Wang et al. [14] reported that the differences in activity over a series of highly comparable Cu/SiO2 catalysts are ascribed to the various functions of both Cu0 and Cu+ species for the hydrogenation of esters to alcohols, where Cu0 mainly facilitated the dissociation of hydrogen, while Cu+ sites were responsible for the adsorption of methoxy and acyl species. Furthermore, the work from Uchijima groups [15] indicated that specific activity for methanol synthesis over copper-based catalysts including various metal oxides, i.e., Ga2O3, ZnO, Cr2O3, ZrO2, A12O3 and SiO2, was ascribed to the ratio of Cu+ to Cu0 on the catalyst surface in the actual reaction conditions, where the amount of Cu+ were stabilized by both surface oxygen and foreign elements. These reports strongly evidenced the existence of a close relationship between the catalysts activity and the valence distribution of copper species. Thus, to retain the initial state distribution of copper species is an important strategy to improve the stability of catalysts. In addition, Oguchi and his co-workers [16] reported that the stability of copper particles was also affected simultaneously by the change of copper valence distribution. Thus, events of differing types in work conditions for catalysts might occur together or as a consequence of another event. Great efforts have been done to explore the chemical state of the copper on the catalyst surfaces. Chen et al. [17] proposed that doping trivalent metal ions into ZnO assists in the formation of monovalent cationic defects on the surface of ZnO, further stabilize monovalent copper on the surface of copper-based catalysts for methanol synthesis during reduction and reaction. Previous research by Chinchen et al. [18] studied the composition of the syngas using Cu-ZnO-Al2O3 as catalyst for methanol synthesis and found that the oxidized copper species on the catalyst surfaces were observed by increasing the ratio of CO2/CO. King groups [19,20] showed that the Cu+ sites can be formed and/or stabilized against reduction to metallic Cu by the addition of alkali metal such as K and Cs to copper catalysts. Recent work by Rodriguez groups [21] reported the CeO2/Cu2O/Cu(111) catalyst was prepared by vapor-depositing Ce onto Cu(111) in an atmosphere of O2, and the complete reduction of Cu2O to Cu was observed after exposing CeO2/Cu2O/Cu(111) to 1.5 torr of H2 by XPS technique. Meanwhile, the performance of CeOx/Cu(111) in a CO2 → CH3OH conversion was investigated and considered that the metal-oxide interface created by the addition of CeOx nanoparticles to Cu performs was highly efficient for the binding and activation of CO2, opening a special reaction pathways for the methanol synthesis [22]. It is expected that many factors will affect the valence state of copper, such as the Cu precursors, preparation methods and reduction process etc., and dynamic transformation between different copper valence occurred where interact with substances in the gas phase composed of oxidizing and reducing gases under distinct experimental conditions. Thus, how to balancing the Cu°/Cu+ ratio of Cu-based catalyst during the reaction process should be a key prerequisite to improve the stability of methanol synthesis. The addition of specific metal (oxides) to Cu-ZnO based catalyst is one of the most convenient and feasible methods to regulate the distribution of Cu(0) and Cu(I) sites. But whether the appropriate metal (oxides) doping can safeguard the distribution of copper state is still unclear. CeO2 has attracted researchers’ interest and is extensively selected as active species, promoters, and/or supports for the fabrication of heterogeneous catalysts in recent years [23–27]. Wang et al. [28] reported that ceria, as a water-tolerant Lewis acid catalyst, possessed excellent catalytic activity in the hydrolysis of 4-methyl-1, 3-dioxane to 1, 3-butanediol and the one-pot synthesis of 1, 3-butanediol from propylene and formaldehyde. Our recent research revealed that oxygen vacancy as an acid active centers enhanced the adsorption of CO2 to form bidentate carbonate over CeZr catalyst which in turn promoted the DMC synthesis from CO2 and MeOH [29]. Wang et al. [30] selected Cu/CeO2 catalyst for the water gas shift reaction (WGS), suggesting that both metallic copper and oxygen vacancies in ceria were involved in the generation of active sites. The wide application of ceria can be attributed to its easily reversible redox reaction (Ce4+ ⇌ Ce3+) under mild conditions (especially in the presence of transition metals), resulting in the ability to store and release oxygen (by creating oxygen vacancy sites). And the Ce-modified Cu-based catalysts positively affected the catalytic performance due to the better Cu dispersion and thermal stability. However, it’s an indisputable fact that researchers paid particular attention on cooperative or synergistic effects involving different configurations of metal-oxide interfaces including Cu-ceria interface and subsequent transformation into CH3OH from CO2 hydrogenation. Studying the effect of doping ceria Cu-ZnO based catalysts on the transformation and distribution of Cu species during hydrogenation process is still rare. Thus, a motivation exists for exploring the evolution of Cu° and Cu+ during reaction with the addition of reversible redox metal (ceria) as an electron promoter. The activity of copper as a methanol synthesis catalyst is substantially boosted by the interaction with ZnO which has only negligible catalytic activity on its own. The Cu-ZnO system has emerged as a benchmark for studying complex promotional interactions in catalysis. And the nature of metal oxides in contact with copper does empirically matter. In this study, cerium was selected as the third component to replacing Al2O3 in the classical Cu-ZnO-Al2O3 (CZAl) prepared by traditional co-precipitation technique for syngas hydrogenation to methanol, meanwhile, traditional CZAl sample prepared under constant conditions was used as a reference. The results manifested that CZCe catalyst exhibited better catalytic behavior than that of CZAl catalyst especially in term of stability. It was considered that the Ce-modified Cu-ZnO catalyst could efficiently retain the concentration and distribution of the active copper species in dynamic balance during the reaction process as well as alleviate particle growth after the very start of the reaction. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation In order to exclude the impact of preparation condition, Cu-ZnO-CeO2 and Cu-ZnO-Al2O3 catalysts were obtained in the identical co-precipitation conditions (i.e. the pH value and temperature for precipitation, component mass ratio, stirring velocity). The schematic diagram of catalyst preparation is displayed in the Scheme S1. Cu(NO3)2·3H2O, Zn(NO3)2·6H2O and Al(NO3)3·9H2O (99 %, AR) were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical ReagentCo., Ltd; Ce(NO3)3·6H2O (99.9 %, AR) and Na2CO3 (99.8 %, AR) were obtained from Tianjin Guangfu Fine Chemical Research Institute and Tianjin Kemiou Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd., respectively. And all catalysts were not further treated. Typically, 9.10 g Cu(NO3)2·3H2O, 5.47 g Zn(NO3)2·6H2O and 1.26 g Ce(NO3)3·6H2O (or 3.68 g Al(NO3)3·9H2O) were dissolved in 66 mL deionized water to fabricate the solution of mixed metal salts (1.0 mol/L). 10.6 g Na2CO3 was dissolved in 100 mL deionized water as the precipitant, simultaneously. The mixed metal salts solution and Na2CO3 precipitant were parallelly dropped to a beaker containing 300 mL of deionized water (65 °C) by two peristaltic pumps under vigorous mechanical stirring. During the entire precipitation process, the pH value of the mixed slurry was controlled to be 7 by adjusting the titration rate of precipitant when the metal salt solution droped at a constant rate. The obtained slurry was aged at 65 °C for 1 h under magnetic stirring and then was hot filtered and washed with the deionized water three times. Finally, the crude material was dried in oven at 80 °C for 12 h and then calcined in static air at 350 °C for 4 h. Meanwhile, Cu-ZnO-Al2O3 as reference catalyst was supposed to make a comparison. These samples were denoted as CZM (M = Ce, Al). Cu-ZnO (CuZn) catalyst was synthesized using the same procedure with mass ratio CuO/ZnO of 6/3. 2.2 Catalyst characterization Specific surface areas of samples were determined from the N2 physisorption isotherms at 77 K using a fully automated ASAP 2010 (Micromeritics) gas adsorption device. Catalysts were outgassed at 250 °C under vacuum for 4 h before measurement. Hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) measurements were carried on AutochemⅡ 2920 auto chemisorption instrument. Generally, 20 mg catalyst was swept for 30 min at 300 °C in N2 atmosphere. After cooling down to 50 °C, it was exposed to a mixture of 10 vol% H2/Ar and heated to 600 °C at the heating rate of 10 °C/min. A thermal conductivity detector (TCD) was used to online monitor the H2 consumption. Transmission electron microscope (TEM) was carried out by JEOL JEM-2100 at an accelerating voltage of 200 kV. The powdered sample was dispersed in ethanol through ultrasound treatment, and then suspended onto a carbon film on the copper mesh. X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurement of the investigated catalysts was conducted on a Rigaku D/Max2500 V diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation of Cu source (λ =0.15406 nm, 40 kV, 30 mA). The scanning speed was kept at 8°/min and the average size of CuO crystallites was calculated according to Scherer equation. For in situ XRD measurement, the catalysts were reduced with a 10 vol% H2/N2 mixture at a flow rate of 20 mL/min for 2 h, meanwhile, temperature ramping programs were performed from room temperature to 250 °C at a rate of 2 °C/min. The gas was switched to the H2/CO/Ar (v/v/v = 10/5/85 %) after cooled down to 230 °C, meanwhile, the XRD patterns were consistently collected from 0 to 6 h. The whole process takes place under atmosphere pressure. The dispersion and exposed surface area of metallic Cu were measured by N2O titration. The sample was reduced in a flow of 10 vol% H2/Ar from room temperature to 400 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min, and H2 consumption in this step was labeled as n1. After cooling to 50 °C under the purge of He flow, the reduced Cu species was superficially oxidized to Cu2O by N2O flow. Then, the catalyst was purged with He flow to remove the residual N2O. Finally, another reduction of Cu2O was carried out from room temperature to 500 °C, and the amount of H2 consumption was denoted as n2. The dispersion and the exposed surface area of Cu were calculated as follows: D C u = 2 n 2 n 1 × 100 % , A C u = 2 N n 2 W × 1.4 × 10 19 Where N is Avogadro's constant (6.02 × 1023 atoms/mol), W represents catalyst mass. Hydrogen temperature-program desorption (H2-TPD) was also conducted on AutochemⅡ2920 auto chemisorption instrument. Generally, 20 mg catalyst was placed on a U-shaped quartz tube with Ar as carrier gas and H2 as reaction gas. Samples were firstly reduced with 10 vol% H2/Ar for 2 h under 250 °C and then cooled down to 50 °C under a flow of He (40 mL/min). The adsorption of H2 was carried out using a feed of 10 vol% H2/Ar for 1 h. The reactor was then purged with Ar for 1 h. Subsequently, the temperature was increased to 800 °C with the rate of 10 °C/min under an Ar flow (40 mL/min). X-ray photoelectron analysis (XPS) was conducted on the ESCALAB 250 energy spectrometer equipped with an Al Kα X-ray radiation source (hν =1486.6 eV). The whole measurement was carried out under a high vacuum. The C1s spectral line (284.8 eV) was selected as the reference to correct the static charge accumulation. 2.3 Evaluation of catalytic performance The catalytic behavior of the CZM (M = Ce, Al) catalysts for methanol synthesis via syngas (H2/CO/CO2) hydrogenation was carried out in fixed-bed reactor with a stainless steel tube reactor (φ9 mm × l450 mm). 0.4 g (40–60 mesh) catalyst granules were initially exposed to the reduction atmosphere containing 10 vol% H2/N2 for 4 h with the velocity of 60 mL/min flow at 250 °C. After cooling to below 100 °C, the reactant gases consisting of 64 vol% H2, 24 vol% CO, 8 vol% CO2 and 4 vol% Ar were passed through the reactor with a flow rate of 30 mL/min to reach 3.0 MPa set by the back pressure valve and subsequently heated up to 230 °C with the heating rate of 2 °C/min. The inlet and outlet streams were on-line analysis by chromatograph (GC-4000A) equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) and hydrogen flame ionization detector (FID). CO conversion (XCO) and methanol yield (STYMeOH) were calculated according to the following formula: X C O = C O i n A r i n − C O out A r o u t C O i n A r i n S T Y M e O H = X C O × n C O + X C O 2 × n C O 2 N o r m a l i z e d S T Y M e O H = S T Y M eOH S T Y M eO H s t a r t × 100 % XCO and XCO2 are the conversion of CO and CO2, respectively. COin, Arin and COout, Arout represent the peak area of CO gases in syngas feed before and after the reaction in the TCD chromatograms. The methanol yield was calculated from the conversion of CO plus CO2 during reaction. STYMeOH is the time space yield of methanol. nCO or nCO2 is the molar flow rate of CO or CO2 into the reactor, respectively. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic activity and stability Cu-ZnO catalysts are widely applied in industrially methanol synthesis and water gas shift reaction, and it has been generally considered that the activity and selectivity for methanol production over the Cu-containing material was substantially boosted by the interaction with ZnO nanoparticles [31–33]. However, the addition of suitably other metal oxides can further improve the performance of CuZn catalysts. Fig. S1 compared the catalytic activity of syngas hydrogenation to methanol over CuZn, CZAl, and CZCe catalysts. It was observed that CZAl and CZCe catalyst exhibited the higher initiation activity in comparison with the CuZn catalyst. Another intriguing phenomenon observed is the STYMeOH over CZCe catalyst could be still maintained as high as 0.600 g·g-1 cat.·h-1, whereas the value for CZAl catalyst remarkably declined to 0.438 g·g-1 cat.·h-1 after 70 h evaluation. Obviously, the addition of ceria promoter on CuZn catalyst greatly improved the stability compared with CZAl catalyst. This prompted us to further investigate the underlying reasons for promoting the stability of catalysts. (1) CO + 2H2 ⇆ CH3OH ΔH298 K = − 90.77 kJ/mol (2) CO2 + 3H2 ⇆ CH3OH + H2O ΔH298 K = − 49.58 kJ/mol (3) CO2 + H2 ⇆ CO + H2O ΔH298 K = +41.19 kJ/mol The catalytic activity of the CZCe and CZAl catalysts as a function of reaction temperature (190−270 °C) are presented in Fig. 1 . It was accepted that Eqs. (1)–(3) were involved in syngas hydrogenation to methanol [34,35]. Typically, low temperature and high pressure was favorable for methanol synthesis. It’s clearly shown that reaction temperature possessed a remarkable effect on catalytic activity. Meanwhile, both CO conversion and STYMeOH exhibited a volcanic variation trend and reached its maximum at 230 °C for both catalysts due to the mutual restraint between thermodynamics and kinetics of chemical reactions. Specifically, STYMeOH increased sharply from 0.14 at 190 °C to 0.67 g·g–1 cat. h–1 at 230 °C for the CZCe catalyst, while it only increase from 0.15 to 0.63 g·g–1 cat. h–1 for CZAl sample. This finding demonstrated that the CZCe catalyst showed the attractive catalytic activity in the whole investigated temperature range from 190 to 270 °C. Table 1 exhibits the effect of Ce additive on the performance of syngas hydrogenation. The reaction temperature used in this work was 230 °C according to the optimization results of temperature deriving from Fig. 1. Comparing with the CZAl sample, it can be obviously found that the CO conversion and the STYMeOH for CZCe catalyst increased by 4.7 % and 0.039 g·g-1 cat. h−1 respectively and this result further confirmed that CZCe catalyst was more propitious to facilitate syngas hydrogenation to methanol process than CZAl sample. It’s well known that the good catalytic stability of Cu-based catalysts plays a key role in the study of catalysts for syngas hydrogenation to methanol [36,37]. Based on above introduction, the active sites reduction on the catalyst surface and the transformation of the Cu active phases during the reaction process are mainly responsible for poor stability [38]. Here, the catalytic stability experiments were performed on the CZCe and traditional CZAl catalysts. As displayed in Fig. 1 (Right), for CZCe catalyst, its normalized STYMeOH decreased by 3% at the initial of 6 h and maintained stable performance during 70 h test. In contrast, the CZAl catalyst suffered relatively rapid deactivation process under identical reaction conditions, especially at the initial reaction period. Concerning its reactivity and obviously superior stability, the CZCe exhibits the potential perspective for methanol synthesis processes from syngas hydrogenation. Thus, a battery of regular characterization techniques such as H2-TPD, N2O-titration, TEM, XRD and XPS were conducted to mainly investigate the relationship between structure evolution and superior stability of CZCe catalyst during the reaction progresses. 3.2 Structural characterization of catalysts during reaction As shown in Table 1, the CZCe catalyst was found to possess a relatively higher BET surface area of 112 m2 g−1, copper dispersions as well as surface areas determined by N2O chemisorption technique, which in turn afforded the high methanol yield. Apart from the fundamental role as a physical spacer, the promoting effect on copper dispersion might be ascribed to the chemical interaction between metal-to-metal oxides to inhibit thermal aggregation of copper nanoparticles. There’s no doubt that the morphology and size of metal nanoparticles are important factors for catalyst behavior in heterogeneous catalysis, which govern the distribution of the active sites. In order to study the morphology and quantify particle sizes of fresh and spent catalysts in a more intuitive method, two samples were probed by transmission electron microscopy (TEM). As displayed in Fig. 2 , the morphology of the fresh CZCe catalyst mainly existed in the form of spherical particles with uniform distribution. The average particle sizes of 8.7 nm on the CZCe-reduced sample can be observed, meanwhile, no obviously change of the average particles sizes (∼9.0 nm) was noted when the reaction lasted up to 70 h which was well consistent with the XRD results. Here, the HRTEM (Fig. 2A) showed the lattice fringe of CeO2 that were surrounded by CuO, indicating the existence of the interface and strong interaction between the active Cu species and the cerium oxides, which was responsible for the well dispersion and anti-sintering for the CZCe catalyst. Si et al. [39] reported similar conclusion that the copper species in form of strongly bound Cu-[Ox]-Ce species are inactive to agglomeration. Unfortunately, CZAl is easier to grow than that of CZCe catalyst after calcined at 350 °C (Fig. S2b). Whereafter, weak particle agglomeration can be observed from the TEM of CZAl catalyst during the reaction (Fig. S2c-e) at the low reaction temperature (230 °C). Here, a consensus can be reached about agglomeration is an inescapable cause of CZAl deactivation. Furthermore, related studies also reported that valence variation of metal species on surface of catalysts can partly be responsible for the agglomeration under work conditions [9,40]. Thus the preservation of morphologies and particle sizes within 70 h on stream, one of the positive factors for the superior stability of the CZCe catalyst during syngas hydrogenation to methanol, may partly profit from the relatively stable copper species active sites, in good agreement with the discussion of the XPS results. This finding demonstrated that introduction of Ce species into Cu-ZnO catalyst not only facilitated the dispersion of Cu nanoparticles, but also restrained the particle agglomeration of catalysts during the reaction process. It could be further evidenced by the intimate contact between the Cu species and ceria as observed in the HRTEM results. Considering the fact that the highly dispersed metallic copper exposed to the atmosphere tended to be oxidized to different extents depending on exposure time and temperature [41] so the in-situ XRD was used to identify the evolution of the crystalline under gaseous environment of CO/H2/Ar (v/v/v = 10 %/5%/85 %). It can be seen from the Fig. 3 that, for the two catalysts, the simultaneous existence of metallic copper and Cu2O were observed in the whole reaction process, according to the existed diffraction peaks centered on 2θ of 36.4° and 43.2° which were attributed to the typical peaks of Cu2O (PDF#65-3288) and Cu (PDF#04-0836), respectively. In order to minimize the phase transformation that probably occurred when exposed to an oxidative atmosphere, the spent samples were cooled down to room temperature in the stainless steel tubular reactor and then carefully sealed in a vacuum bag for subsequent XRD and XPS analysis. XRD patterns of the CZCe-calcined, CZCe-reduced and CZCe-reaction-X h samples are shown in Fig. 4 A, in which the peak centered in 31.8° and 34.4° were attributed to ZnO species (PDF#36-1451). In comparison, no characteristic peaks corresponding to ceria were detected, which implied the high dispersion of Ce species or the presence of amorphous ceria. Two apparent diffraction peaks in the calcined CZCe catalyst can be observed at 35.6° and 38.7° which were assigned to the typical peaks of CuO (PDF#48-1548). For the reduced CZCe catalyst, a strong peak at around 43.3° along with a weak peak centered at 36.5° were attributed to Cu and Cu2O species, respectively, as well as the almost disappearance of the CuO peaks. The results demonstrated that CuO phase were mainly reduced to Cu° species after reduction process. It was found that the CZCe-reaction-14 h displayed the distinct and intensive diffraction peaks of Cu2O compared with the CZCe-reduced catalyst, and an explanation for this was that partial Cu species were converted into Cu2O in the initial hydrogenation reaction. Correspondingly, the concentration of Cu° sites on the catalyst surfaces declined with the increase of Cu+ content in the initial stage of the reaction, as listed in Table 3. Furthermore, the diffraction peaks of Cu and Cu2O were maintained with a further increase of reaction time from 14 to 70 h. It simultaneously revealed that the mean particle sizes of copper species may be hardly enlarged with the prolonging of the reaction time. The calculated mean crystallite sizes of Cu and Cu2O according to Scherer equation are presented in Table 2 for CZCe and CZAl catalysts. It can be observed that there was no apparent crystallite sizes change for copper species. The above discussion indicated that part of Cu° was reoxidized to Cu2O at the early stage of the reaction on the surface of CZCe catalyst, and the change of crystallite sizes of copper particles was inconspicuous over the entire reaction period. Here, although providing the hardly fluctuation for copper species crystallite sizes over CZAl, the week agglomeration presented in the TEM (Fig. S2) was observed, possibly attributed to the agglomeration of ZnO species, which consensus to the reported by Liang et al. [42]. Compared to CZAl catalyst, broad CuO diffraction peaks were observed for the CZCe catalyst, suggesting the increase of its dispersion after being modified by ceria (Fig. S3). This was in accordance with the smaller particle size and higher dispersion observed by TEM and N2O titration. Luo et al. [43] have claimed that the addition of Zr, Ce, or La decreased the crystallite size of Co3O4, which would promote the catalytic activity. Chen and co-workers [35] have reported that the growth of Cu0 crystallites can be effectively prohibited during reduction as a result of strong CuO-CeO2 synergetic interaction. Here it could be concluded that the catalyst with doping ceria was more favorable to improve the dispersion and stability of active metal. 3.3 Cu species transition during reaction As the main active component, the valence state distribution of copper species have a great influence on the catalyst performance. Thus XPS profiles of the catalysts were measured to determine the chemical states of Cu species. As shown in Fig. S5, the chemical state of Cu species was +2 value in calcined samples given the existing of the satellite peak at around 942−944 eV and peaks located at 953.8 eV and 933.7 eV belonging to Cu2p1/2 and Cu2p3/2, respectively [44,45]. In addition, it could be seen that the Cu2p binding energy of calcined-CZCe catalyst moved towards low binding energy compared with CZAl catalyst, and the H2-TPR results showed that the reduction peak shifted to the lower temperature (Fig. S4). Those results implied the addition of ceria had effect on the electron density of copper, thus changed the binding energy of Cu-O bond. Recently, Ai et al. [46] depicted that the ratio of Cu+/(Cu° + Cu+) increased with the increase of Ce loading, demonstrating the existence of electron interaction between Cu species and Ce promoter. As shown in Fig. 5 A and 5D, two strong peaks centered at ∼952.2 eV and 932.4 eV for two samples can be found in the reduced catalysts, thereby indicating that Cu2+ was reduced to Cu° and/or Cu+ by H2 at elevated temperature (up to 250 °C). Considering the minor dissimilarity of binding energy, Cu° and Cu+ can be distinguished powerfully through auger electron spectra of Cu LMM for CZCe-reduced and CZCe-reaction-X h catalysts. As presented in Fig. 5B, a wide and asymmetric Cu LMM XAES spectra can be observed for CZCe catalysts, manifesting the co-existing of Cu° and Cu+ with a small amount of Cu2+. The relatively surface contents of each Cu valence can be obtained by deconvolution of the spectra into three overlapping peaks at ∼914.2, ∼916.8 and ∼918.5 eV, corresponding to Cu+, Cu° and Cu2+, respectively [47,48]. The existence of less Cu2+ species in catalysts was probably due to the reoxidation of the catalysts caused by transfer/reaction process, considering that the surface reduction process of CZCe and CZAl catalysts have been completed under 250 °C from the H2-TPR results (Fig. S4). Here, given the same process from preservation to the characterization of the catalyst after the reaction, the changes of copper species on the catalyst surfaces caused by the external environment were ignored. From the deconvolution results in Table 3, the ratio of surface Cu°/Cu+ sharply decreased from 2.35 to 1.90 after 14 h reaction, revealing the conversion of copper into cuprous oxide during syngas hydrogenation process, in good agreement with the XRD profiles in Fig. 4. Furthermore, the Cu°/Cu+ ratios (∼1.90) have negligible fluctuation with the prolonging of the reaction time over CZCe catalyst until 70 h, manifesting that the introduction of ceria improved the stability of distribution of surface Cu species. There is no doubt that the equilibrium of the valence distribution of copper species during the reaction will maintain the original activity of the catalyst on the premise of constant of morphology and particle sizes. In other words, the excellent stability of CZCe catalyst can be associated with the stability of active sites to a large extent. For the CZAl catalyst, Cu2p spectra (Fig. 5D) showed a shoulder peak at around 934.4 eV when the reaction time continued to 42 h. The fitted results of two overlapping peaks at 932.2 and 934.4 eV in the Fig. 5D are shown in Fig. 5E, suggesting that the Cu2+ content increased with the extended reaction time. Subsequently, Cu LMM XAES Fig. 5F displayed the same trend, and the Cu°/Cu+ ratio obviously decreased in the initial 42 h from 1.97 to 1.36, whereas the ratio possessed no obviously change from 42 to 70 h, which was consistent with the stability result of the CZAl catalyst that normalized STYMeOH declined rapidly at the initial stage and then tended to be stable with the extension of reaction time. Thus, interruption of concentration and distribution of active sites along with weak particles growth were responsible for the deactivation of the CZAl catalyst. Moreover, Skorodumova et al. [49] have reported that, under reduction conditions, the presence of two Ce3+ atoms declared the formation of an oxygen vacancy in the containing CeOx catalysts; meanwhile, the most befitting position of these two Ce3+ atoms was related with the oxygen vacancy. Li et al. [50] found that the formation of oxygen vacancies in the Mn-Cu-Ce-O solid solution enhanced the content of Cu+ species, which was favorable for CO oxidation. It’s well known that the presence of Cu° promoted the reduction of Ce4+ to Ce3+ and further generated oxygen vacancy. Therefore, the ratio of OV/(OL+ OV+ OC) might be used to monitor the transition of Ce4+/Ce3+ during the reaction process. Three peaks in CZCe catalysts were observed in O1s spectra (Fig. 5C) which corresponded to lattice oxygen (∼530.2 eV), oxygen vacancies (∼531.6 eV) and chemisorbed oxygen species (∼532.2 eV), respectively [44]. As listed in Table 3, the increase of the concentration of oxygen vacancies on the catalyst surface from 16.2 % to ∼23.0 % confirmed the transition of Ce4+ ⇆ Ce3+ during syngas hydrogenation. The percentage of oxygen vacancies retained at 23 % which was strongly related to the dynamic equilibrium of Ce4+ and Ce3+ along with the reaction time. The whole reaction was carried out in a steady state that could be responsible for the negligible change on the CZCe catalyst surfaces. In view of the above discussion, the distinct interaction between Cu and Ce species can not only improve the structural stability of the catalyst, but also maintain the ratio of Cu°/Cu+. These factors were significantly vital to determine the catalytic stability. 3.4 Effect of Cu0/Cu+ ratio on the stability of catalyst Ni et al. [51] excluded the effect of metal particle size in order to probe the influence of electron effect for Ni/ZrO2 catalysts. Similarly, in this study, particle sizes of CZCe and CZAl catalysts presented no significantly difference as confirmed by XRD and TEM results, indicating that the effect of the particle size on catalytic stability was minimized. Hence, it’s meaningful to monitor the impact of copper species distribution during the reaction on catalyst stability. Based on the currently proposed reaction mechanism in CO2 hydrogenation to methanol, the dissociative adsorbed hydrogen over the copper surface transferred to the adsorption sites of CO2 for stepwise hydrogenation to form methanol [52,53]. The quantity of desorption H2 determined by H2-TPD (Fig. S6) between 50−320 °C for CZCe and CZAl catalysts, respectively, had obviously positive correlation with the SACu of reduced catalysts surface observed by N2O titration, indicating the increase of active hydrogen species with the increase of Cu° sites. Wang et al. [14] reported that, in the hydrogenation of esters to alcohols, Cu+ sites were responsible for the adsorption of methoxy and acyl species, while Cu° mainly facilitated the dissociation of hydrogen. Gong et al. [54] suggested that the coexistence of Cu° and Cu+ was favorable for promoting efficiency of the Cu/SiO2 catalyst. So, the STYMeOH was strongly related to both Cu° and Cu+ species and a suitable ratio of Cu°/Cu+ was vital for the catalytic performance [55,56]. Cu-ZnO catalyst doping cerium oxides exhibited superior stability compared to the traditional Cu-ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst. Characterization results proved that no significant morphology and size changes could be observed for fresh and spent catalysts. Thus, it was a research topic to study the relationship between copper valence change and the catalytic behavior. Fig. 6 exhibits the relationship between the STYMeOH and the ratio of Cu°/Cu+ along with reaction time. It can be found that the methanol yield for CZCe catalyst decreased by 3% in the initial 14 h, then decreased by 1.7 % between 14 h and 42 h. Partial transition of Cu° into Cu+ species (Fig. 4A and Table 3 ) during the initial stage of the reaction led to the apparent decline of Cu°/Cu+ ratio, and then the value had no significant change in the course of the subsequent reaction, with a slight decrease in STYMeOH from 0.677 to 0.665 g·g-1 cat.·h-1. However, with the progress of the reaction, the content of either Cu+ or Cu° sites on the catalyst surface decreased, along with the increase of Cu2+ concentration for CZAl catalyst. Correspondingly, the ratio of Cu°/Cu+ showed a decline trend with the methanol yield from initial stage to 70 h. In summary, there were two main reasons for the decline of catalytic performance for CZAl catalyst: sintering phenomenon appeared in real reaction conditions; the active copper species (Cu+ and/or Cu°) were liable to be oxidized to Cu2+ and then the ratio of Cu°/Cu+ gradually increased, thereby descending the synergistic effect of Cu+ and Cu° active sites. Fig.7 showed the transformation of different valence of copper species under different conditions to a certain extent. The calcined catalysts of CZCe and CZAl are completely oxidized to Cu2+ and Ce4+ in air at 350 °C. In a H2 flow, the reduction of CuO to Cu and Cu2O is achieved for both catalysts. Also, Ce3+ is generated due to the presence of Cu. Similar results were reported by Bu and Sripada et al. [57,58]. Subsequently, the dynamic balance of active copper species Cu° ⇌ Cu+ of CZCe catalyst can be found under the redox atmosphere (H2/CO/CO2/H2O) due to the electronic interaction between copper and cerium, greatly improving the catalyst stability. On the contrary, for CZAl catalyst, Cu2+ formation, which have no catalytic activity, takes place by the oxidation of Cu° and/or Cu+, consequently causing the active sites decrease on the catalyst surface and descending the synergistic effect of Cu+ and Cu° active sites. It could be concluded that the contents and ratios with different valence states seriously affected the catalytic performance in hydrogenation of CO bonds. On the other hand, the SACu of CZCe catalyst also tended to be stable after 14 h (∼31 m2·g-1 cat.) as shown in Table 2. Thus, it’s believed that the catalyst stability would be enhanced if the distribution of valence states and the concentration of exposed active sites possessed no apparent wave with the reaction time. 3.5 Origin of enhanced catalyst stability In methanol synthesis from syngas hydrogenation, the structural transformation of the catalyst mainly included two categories: decrease of Cu surface area through particle growth due to thermal migration and agglomeration and the dynamic conversion of valence state of copper species [59,60]. The catalyst stability with the high initial activity might be greatly improved if it possessed no distinct structure evolution with prolonging the reaction time. Through the previous discussion, two requisites must be satisfied for an excellent catalyst as following: a secure SACu to guarantee the concentration of active sites; a dynamic balance of Cu°/Cu+ ratio during the reaction to ensure the synergistic action. The SACu measured by N2O measurement showed no significant change. It could be explained by the fact that the existence of strong metal-oxide interaction was favorable for thermodynamic stability. Additionally, although the definite reason for the positive result (stable of the Cu°/Cu+ ratio) over CZCe catalyst was still unclear, it could be proposed that it might follow dynamic equilibrium of valence state for Cu/CuxO, CeOx/CeO2 due to the facile, reversible redox cycle of Ce4+ ⇌ Ce3+ and Cu° ⇌ Cu+, and thus to a great extent promoting the stable ratio of Cu°/Cu+ during the reaction process (Table 3). This process is briefly shown in Scheme1 . More than half of copper oxide were reduced to Cu° after the reduction in 10 vol% H2/N2 atmosphere. Furthermore, the reduction of Ce4+ to Ce3+ ions (creating oxygen vacancies) was achieved in the presence of Cu° in reduction gas or feed gas atmosphere. CO2 and/or H2O as Lewis base can be adsorbed on oxygen vacancy (Lewis acid) [61,62], leading to the regeneration of Ce4+ through re-oxidation of Ce3+ species. Meanwhile, Cu+ derived from Cu° + Ce4+ → Cu+ + Ce3+ in syngas atmosphere were reduced to Cu°. In summary, the coexisting of two peculiar redox pairs (Cu+/Cu° and Ce4+/Ce3+) would be responsible to the dynamic equilibrium of Cu°/Cu+ sites during the reaction process. The cooperative effect between copper species and ceria significantly improved the catalyst stability in the syngas hydrogenation to methanol. 4 Conclusion This work discussed the influence of replacing Al2O3 with CeO2 (a reversible redox metal oxide) in the classical Cu-ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst on the existence form of Cu valence state during methanol synthesis. The CZCe catalyst was prepared by facile co-precipitation which can achieve the intimate contact between surface of copper species and metal oxides, and the connection between catalyst structure transition during the reaction and superior stability over CZCe catalyst was established through TEM, XRD and XPS measurements which can monitor the evolution of morphology, phase and valence state of CZCe systematically. It was suggested here that the doping of cerium additive into Cu-ZnO catalyst exhibited a remarkable positive effect on the catalyst stability, which resulted from the preservation the ratio of Cu0/Cu+ on catalyst surface and retard oxidation to Cu2+ as well as particle growth due to the strong and complex electron interactions of the copper/ceria phase (Cu/Cu2O/CuO, Ce3+/Ce4+) during syngas hydrogenation. Meanwhile, a dynamic equilibrium mechanism of valence states for Cu(0)/Cu(I), Ce(III)/Ce(IV) during reaction process was speculated, which was responsible for the relatively stable copper valence state. This work therefore provide a useful guideline for dynamically tuning the distributions and/or concentrations of active component of methanol synthesis catalyst. coredata.dc:description: Cu-ZnO based catalysts are of industrial importance for methanol synthesis. In this work, Cu-ZnO-CeO2 (CZCe) catalyst has been prepared via conventional co-precipitation technique and applied for syngas hydrogenation to methanol with the purpose to study the effect of reversible redox metal oxide (ceria) on the distribution of valence state of active Cu species. Herein, CZCe catalyst exhibited the outstanding catalytic performance with initial methanol yield as high as 0.665 g·g–1 cat.·h–1 and the STYMeOH could well be maintained with a high value (0.600 g·g–1 cat.·h–1) at 230 °C after 70 h of evaluation, which exceeded the reference Cu-ZnO-Al2O3 (CZAl) catalyst prepared by the same method. The excellent performance could be attributed to ceria doping tended to dynamically tune the distributions and/or concentrations of Cu+ and Cu° species on the catalyst surfaces and retard the conversion of Cu δ + (δ < 2) to Cu2+ in the process of reaction.
coredata.dc:title: Insight into the positive effect of Cu0/Cu+ ratio on the stability of Cu-ZnO-CeO2 catalyst for syngas hydrogenation
